author: timbeiko
content:
Apologies for derailing this a bit, but one of the concerns that caused <@!543900561460822016> to look into this AIUI is that we need a fairly easy way to generate JSON RPC diffs for London, and a lot of tooling is currently blocked on this. 

I understand that moving the entire spec over "just" for London may seem fast and need additional discussions, but OTOH this does seem like a very easy way to generate a diff. The other option is to open EIPs like we did for the block headers (e.g. https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-3041). It seems unlikely we'll have re-transcribed the entire spec as <@!104006934562107392> was starting in the next week or so, but that's the timeline where we'd need the 1559 diffs. 

I don't have a strong opinion on how we do it, but just want to highlight the two different timescales.

author: sky.cactus
content: Ethereum and Ethereum Classic teams have butted heads *many* times on licensing.

author: sky.cactus
content: ETC refuses to do anything public domain, and ETH is staunchly against anything that isn't public domain.

author: sky.cactus
content: The problem would be solved if someone would hire a lawyer to draft up "public domain with patent protection".

author: sky.cactus
content: Which is a gaping hole in the mess of licenses out there.

author: sky.cactus
content: Apache 2 provides patent troll protection, while public domain doesn't explicitly do so (I don't think it has ever been tested in court though).

author: sky.cactus
content: It is unfortunate, but may be the best way to avoid the quagmire that is licensing.

author: sky.cactus
content: Ethereum Foundation has historically done everything 100% free/open.  Apache is certainly permissive, but it isn't "free for everyone no strings attached".

author: sky.cactus
content: Many of the clients (all maybe?) are licensed differently, but all of the protocol definition stuff is unconstrained/untethered.

author: sky.cactus
content: (note: I'm biased toward public domain/unlicensed, so you should get second opinions here)

author: sky.cactus
content: Just know that this issue has come up multiple times in the EIPs repository, and I think it is the number one reason that Ethereum Classic devs no longer contribute to the EIPs repository.
